file_content.text: It has been my honor to serve you.
Most cordial greetings. I am Zan Threelow, Republic protocol officer. Welcome to Makeb and Keylander Station.
Please hold all questions. Supreme Chancellor Saresh and her delegation are arriving.
Assembled friends... the Republic owes its continued survival to this brave Jedi. Entire worlds would be smoldering ruins if not for this hero's courage and sacrifice.
I was in the right places at the right times. Anyone in this room would have done the same, given the chance.
I'm no one special.
Perhaps, but would they have succeeded? You carry burdens that would break others--and we have need of that strength.
My friends, this wise Jedi Master has protected the Republic from dangers without and within time and again. I can think of no greater guardian of our security.
Protecting the Republic takes more than a lone Jedi. It requires the vigilance and strength of everyone safekeeping our society.
I share that duty with all.
Astute words--and especially fitting here.
Everyone... this brave soldier assumed command of Havoc Squad in its darkest hour and led it to many victories. I regret that such heroism must remain classified.
Havoc Squad doesn't ask for fame, Madame Chancellor. It's enough for us to know the Republic is safe.
We're just humble soldiers.
I want the galaxy to know you're a hero. People need them--especially now.
I ask everyone here with me to honor this brave captain, who thwarted an attack on the Republic by no less than an Imperial Grand Admiral.
I thought you were throwing me a surprise party. Not that I'll turn down another job... but I wouldn't mind a little blowout bash once in a while.
I expected a parade.
Forgive me for placing business ahead of pleasure. Hazard of the office.
Thank you for coming. I'm a great admirer of your victories in service to the Republic. Whenever I require someone who will not fail us, you always come to mind.
Always a pleasure, Chancellor.
The honor is ours--and rest assured, I would not call you here without good reason.
It's always a privilege to stand before the Republic's greatest heroes. Time and again, you have not only saved us from the enemy but brought us closer to ultimate triumph.
I may have deprived the Empire of its leader, but I won't rest until the worlds the Sith have taken are free once more.
I've only begun to fight.
Liberation is precisely what brings us here today.
The Emperor's Children may be gone, but if I've learned anything about Sith, there are more hidden threats awaiting us.
Our foe isn't easily beaten.
Unwelcome surprises are exactly what bring us here.
Still getting used to people calling me "Major." Wasn't that long ago I was a lieutenant.
Explains all these promotions.
Thanks to your defeat of General Rakton and impressive victories on Corellia, military recruitment has surged. We'll need those soldiers.
Not to brag, but I took down an Imperial Grand Admiral and his flagship. You wouldn't believe how much ammo that took.
That's putting it lightly.
You should consider enlisting in the Republic military, Captain. The ammunition there is free.
I doubt all these people came just to hear you flatter me, Chancellor. The situation on Makeb must be bad.
I take it things are serious.
The crisis we face is unexpected and severe. I require my best advisors--and most able problem-solvers.
You know better than to sweet-talk me, Chancellor. There's trouble--what do you need me to do about it?
Flattery doesn't interest me.
I'm glad to see success and fame haven't changed you.
Victory over the Empire lies within our grasp. But first, we must face a cowardly act of unwarranted aggression. Supreme Commander Malcolm?
Thirteen days ago, the Hutt Cartel violated Republic space and seized the planet Makeb. They've blockaded the system with thirty Ajuur-class heavy cruisers.
Makeb's citizens have formally pledged to join the Republic if we respond to their crisis. We will not abandon them to the Hutts' brutality.
The planet must have something of value if the Hutts are risking outright war for it.
Hutts only attack for profit.
I don't care what motivates them. I want their blight removed from our space.
The galaxy has suffered upheaval, but the Hutts haven't been interested in galactic conquest for fifteen thousand years.
A strange attack by the Hutts.
This war has created opportunities for the greedy and unscrupulous.
Invading a planet is way beyond casinos and spice smuggling. The slugs have upped their game.
A bold move by the Hutts.
The Hutts haven't organized a military operation of this scale for millennia--and I want it to stay that way.
I hate to suggest my way out of a job, but everyone has a price. Make the Cartel a generous offer, and they'll go.
Buy off the Hutts. They'll go.
I don't negotiate with despots who take planets hostage.
If we're willing to fight the Hutt Cartel for control of a planet that's been neutral up until now, we must have good reason.
Makeb must be quite a world.
Makeb is a paradise. Quality of living standards significantly above the galactic average. Thriving mining and tourism industries. A world worth saving--and having.
If the Hutts want trouble, they just bought more than they can handle. I'll stomp those slugs into jelly.
Let's crush the Cartel.
Our response to this attack must be unequivocal. I will not see us defeat the Empire only to war with a parade of aggressors.
Severe atmospheric conditions on Makeb make large-scale troop landings impossible. We need help from local resistance forces to pull this off.
One of Makeb's business leaders, Shalim Avesta, is awaiting you on the surface. I want you working closely with him.
We couldn't have freed Balmorra or Corellia without help from the locals.
Native support is invaluable.
Shalim is a patriot who led his people to embrace the Republic. We mustn't desert him.
If he's bold enough to stand up to the Hutts, he'll be worth listening to.
I look forward to our meeting.
Shalim would sooner accept a live grenade than Hutt rule.
Can we count on all the locals for backup, or is Shalim the exception?
I hope he's not all we've got.
The citizens are ill-equipped for armed assistance. They'll mostly provide enemy intelligence.
If you want this done right, let me handle it my way. I'll only take this job if I don't have to salute anyone.
I work best alone.
No one's asking you to compromise your ideals, Captain. Shalim is a resource--use him.
I'm surprised the planet's army didn't put up a fight. Or did the Hutts defeat them?
Doesn't Makeb have a military?
Makeb's entire military strength came from hired mercenaries. The Hutts simply bought them off.
This Shalim sounds like he belongs in a boardroom, not on a battlefield.
Businessmen are useless to me.
You'll need local expertise for this mission. Shalim and his forces can provide that.
Liberating Makeb is your top priority--but I want the Hutts' ambitions ended permanently. Grand Master Satele Shan has insight regarding our enemy's future plans.
The Jedi Council has meditated on the Cartel's actions. We believe that Makeb is a staging point for a larger attack on the entire galaxy.
The Hutts will not be allowed to expand their dominion at our expense.
It's always an honor to face down the enemies of the Republic, Madame Chancellor.
I'll be proud to stop them.
When our enemy realizes who they're facing, I predict a hasty retreat.
If the Republic cuts a deal with the Cartel, we could team up and take down the Empire together.
Could Hutts be good allies?
If there's to be any negotiation, I intend for it to be entirely one-sided.
No planet deserves Hutt rule. I'll see the galaxy safe from their kind if I have to kick every last one straight into the Void myself.
They're a plague. I'm a cure.
I'll settle for a crippling strike that reminds them of their place.
A shuttle will transport you to Shalim Avesta's encampment on the surface. Go now, and show the galaxy the Republic is not to be trifled with.
Greetings. I am Zan Threelow, Republic protocol officer of Keylander Station. I am currently unable to assist you.
The Supreme Chancellor requested a meeting.
Welcome back! I was informed that you survived a terrifying ordeal. You have my deepest admiration. Ah, here they are....
We had no idea the planet was that unstable. Our offer was made in good faith.
Millions of hungry mouths to feed and nothing to show for it. You pledged Makeb to us, Shalim--and you knew it was doomed.
You knew the groundquakes were getting worse. You used the Republic, knowing we'd be obligated to help your people even if you had nothing to offer in return.
They didn't know Makeb was doomed--only that the groundquakes were increasing after the Hutts took over.
It wasn't that simple.
They didn't voice all of their suspicions, but they were trying to save lives. Would we have acted any different?
That hardly matters now.
What's done is done. We have a vessel filled with millions of refugees who need food, water and medical treatment.
Regardless, people need help.
And a home. My people can't live on that ark forever. They're packed in like cargo.
We got those people off Makeb. What happens next is their problem, not ours.
We have no obligation to them.
You can't just abandon us. Planet or not, we're Republic citizens now!
This is a debacle. We came here seeking resources to defeat the Sith Empire. Instead, we're walking away with debts and obligations.
What about the Hutt leaders? You negotiated a peace agreement with them, didn't you?
He's right. The Cartel leaders have promised to support the Republic wholeheartedly.
Yes, we've made them allies.
So we have a worthless ally and a broken one. Still... the Hutts possess considerable wealth.
Hutt promises aren't worth the time it takes to hear them lie. They're all scum--we can never trust them.
That deal is mostly worthless.
I have no intention of trusting them--but I'll exploit their fear of you for all it's worth.
As I recall, you wanted to abandon the Cartel leaders on Makeb.
You were against that deal.
Cooler heads prevailed. My point is, the Republic did benefit from rescuing us.
Only the Cartel leaders who needed rescuing agreed to this alliance. Fortunately, they possess most of the wealth and power. They'll neutralize any holdouts.
The Hutts can provide aid.
We can hold their warships in reserve and use them to protect vulnerable systems. Meanwhile, the Hutts will build a colony for Makeb's people.
I had to twist your arm to call the Republic. Glad you finally swallowed that "spirit of independence"?
I want to speak with my operative in private. Please excuse us.
It's time for the Republic to wipe the Empire from the galaxy. Everyone who has chosen our side will play a role.
Draft them all for the war.
The Hutt Cartel will place its warships under our command, and the people of Makeb will find new homes in our armies and factories.
I never thought.... How can you treat us like this?
It's better than the alternative--and you should be more appreciative. Dismissed.
You've made the best of an unfortunate situation. Well done.
The Hutts want to be on the winning side of this war, and you've shown them who that is. We have you alone to thank for this alliance.
All Jedi are taught that our power should be used to bring people together for peace.
This was about helping others.
A great many have seen your example and responded--and I need that beacon in the darkness more than ever.
Let's hope what we achieved here will ripple across the galaxy and rally more forces to our cause.
We made a powerful example.
This victory has already been noted by several independent factions. Our diplomats will be quite busy.
Havoc Squad isn't one man or woman. I'm always part of a team--and we're with you all the way.
Not just me--my team, too.
I wish I could offer you some much-deserved rest, Major--but the war has other plans for us both.
People are naturally drawn to me. I think it's because I exude confidence and power.
Always bet on a winner.
No one could ever doubt your audacity, Captain--which is why I must continue to request your services.
We still have plenty of fighting to do. The Empire isn't falling anytime soon.
The war isn't over yet.
Indeed--which brings me to my next point.
It's wise of you to recognize my importance.
I'm your greatest asset.
The Republic wouldn't be nearly as close to victory if not for you--a fact I intend to rely upon.
For too long, the Republic has wasted time reacting to the enemy. We must fight this war to win by going on the offensive.
The Hutts destroyed Makeb. It seems only fair they should pay the cost of caring for its refugees.
The Republic needs to establish a haven for war victims. I can't think of anyone more deserving than the people of Makeb.
The Hutts have plenty of credits to fund the construction of new homes--and we can use their fleet to protect them.
My uncle is a businessman, Chancellor--but in this case he's telling the truth.
With our new friends' wealth and warships, we've gained a substantial advantage over the Empire. That doesn't address the problem of Makeb's people, however. I need a solution.
After everything we've been through, to receive such generosity... thank you all.
The people of Makeb need someone guiding them to their new home. I think you're the right person for that job, Shalim.
You'll be a good leader.
I'm... not. But you've shown me what a true leader looks like. I'll follow that example.
[Flirt] This was for Lemda.
Fine. You win. Here's my holofrequency--call it often.
You got your people through this mess--but I don't think you're the leader Makeb needs anymore. It's better if businessmen like you retire.
It's time you stepped down.
I can't step down. My people need leadership.
The Republic government will see to Makeb's citizens. If we require your services, we'll contact you.
I wish to speak with my agents privately. Excuse us.
You said the Republic would help us--not make us indentured servants!
Savor this victory. Return to the war's front lines and press our advantage. Together, we will be triumphant.
I did it for a snappish woman who deserves a new home. I'll miss you, Lemda.
Make sure the Hutts build you a nice place, Lemda. You deserve the best.
